results.content:
This is not a good course.  Best practices are not used and it only very briefly discusses topics.  The course comes with code that is already written out and this greatly reduces the amount of learning.  Some of the code that is already written in the project needs to be written by the student.  One example of this is the authentication functions.  While authentication isn't GraphQL specific, it is important for a student to get practice implementing it with GraphQl.  This includes writing the code for it.  

The first half of the course includes writing code on the server to make the client show the correct code.  While doing this, Apollo Client is not used at all.  This makes half of the code written in the first half a waste of time.

My opinion is that the course should have been split up into two sections, server and client.  The server can be completely written using the GraphQL Playground and this would take away the unnecessary code written using the fetch function.  

I have taken several courses on GraphQL and this is by far the worst.  The course has potential, but it is should be titled GraphQL by Cloning a Git Repo.

response.content:
Sorry you didn't like the approach taken in the course. Most people thankfully do. You're entitled to your opinions of course, but some of your comments are misleading.
The repository provided as a starting point for the Job Board example has no GraphQL functionality whatsoever. We write all the GraphQL code in the course. It's absolutely not all "already written out".
We start by writing our own GraphQL client with fetch because it's important to understand GraphQL HTTP requests well, before moving on to a ready-made library like Apollo Client. Apollo Client is just one specific implementation of the GraphQL over HTTP specification.
Developing the server separately from the client sounds like a "waterfall model". I believe it's better to incrementally add end-to-end features.

results.content:
Great course for learning the latest in Graphql/Apollo, especially for those familiar with React.  I took this course after taking Stephen Grider's Modern React and Node w/ React Fullstack courses (which are great btw).  I chose this GraphQL course because it uses the latest GraphQL and React best practices including using Apollo-Client and React-Hooks (latter half of course).  Furthermore, the course was great because the first half shows you how to implement GraphQL without such shortcuts so you both have a sense of how everything works under the hood as well as depth of understanding for how to implement GraphQL for a variety of implementations.  Good, thorough yet succinct course.  Also, Mirko was extremely quick in responding to 2 questions I posted which was a pleasant surprise, especially given my issues largely turned out to be due to my own mistakes/misses. 
 Thank you for a great course Mirko!

results.content:
The content of the course was a solid intro, but I found aspects of the way it was delivered outright distracting or unhelpful. For example, throughout the course, there was a LOT of typing one thing, trying it, removing it completely to do something a different way, and then re-typing it the first way. This especially made the Apollo Client with React Hooks section feel like a typing exercise rather than something relevant and instructive in terms of GraphQL- do you want useState in there or not? If you're going to use it later, why not just comment it out temporarily and mention that we'll come back to it? I found myself pre-emptively commenting out large blocks of code, and coming back to them when they were needed later- this was the best way that I found to actually enable me to keep up with the videos while actually learning things, rather than pausing constantly to re-type text that I had just deleted.

Because of educational anti-patterns like the one above, and the very slow speech of the instructor (I ended up watching most of the course at 1.25x, while working through every example, just to get through it at a reasonable pace), there's not as much packed into this 5.5 hours as you might hope. GraphQL Directives Inline Fragments, and Meta fields aren't mentioned, and developers are likely to encounter these in the real world.

As a general overview, the course did contain the necessary info, but due to the delivery, I found it an exhausting chore to get through over two days, even while sipping coffee throughout.

response.content: Thanks for the feedback. Sometimes I show different ways to do a certain thing so that students are aware of the options, or to explain the logic behind a certain approach. You don't have to type everything as soon as I do in the video. In fact I would recommend watching a full video first, then update your own code at the end.

results.content:
The course covers the basics of how to set up a simple GraphQL server and plumb its usage into a small React application.

Where I think the course is a bit weak, is that it wastes time developing a server that is not real world when there are turn key solutions that would have worked just as well, e.g. Graphcool (hosted or locally installed). Secondly, the GraphQL integration in the React client is not illustrative of current React best practices i.e. no Redux (or Apollo) provider - HOC prop setting pattern. 

What the course gets right though, is that its introduction to the basics of how to use GraphQL to query and mutate data on the server are well explained.

Overall I enjoyed the course and found it informative, but not quite for the reasons I was originally hoping for (hence the 3 stars). As such, I'd only really be happy recommending the course to beginners.

results.content:
Quick disclaimer, I recently joined a project at work that used GraphQL applied to a ReactJS stack with Apollo, and had very limited time to become proficient at both GraphQL and Apollo. So as you can imagine, not only was time of the essence, but a 10-20 hour course was not even an option.

I picked this course as it received relatively good reviews and was surprisingly short while also fitting my project's tech stack. My expectations were high as you can imagine, and thankfully, I was not dissapointed (mostly).

PRO's:
The course is perfectly paced, not too slow or fast, but just right. Also, as a complete and total beginner in GraphQL, I left with a solid understanding of both GraphQL, and Apollo. I loved how the presenter showed how to do things progressively, and even included lots of best-practice improvements. Also, a major factor of why I loved the course is the presenter doesn't rush important concepts, and actually revisited most of them quite frequently to make sure they stick. In retrospective, it's kind of mindblowing he was able to explain so many things so clearly and patiently in the barely 3 hours of course content.

CON's:
A major con of the course is that it's quite old by fast paced modern web dev standards, as it was built with Apollo Server v1 (we're at V2.0 now). This means the default Apollo Installation will not work with his code, and most online documentation is worthless. This wasn't a dealbreaker though, as I could the presenter provides a Github Repo with all the correct v1.0 dependencies and code solutions if you get stuck, but it's something worth knowing. Also, Apollo Server doesn't change too drastically between v1.0/2.0, at least in the core pillar fundamentals.

Also, fair warning, while the course does not require prior Express/React knowledge, I STRONGLY recommend you are at least familiar with the basics as the sample project is quite Express/React heavy.

Overall, I LOVED the course, and would recommend it 100% to anyone looking to learn the GraphQL/Apollo basics. I wouldn't have hesitated to rate this course 5 stars, but the fact the course was done in v1.0 with no prior warning (he added a chapter on migrating to v2.0, but this was at the very end of the entire course, wish he at least had a warning at the start) ended up taking half a star off.

Anyways, FANTASTIC COURSE!!! ♥

results.content:
Excellent course. The best I have come across that tackles GraphQL. Mr Nasato has done a great job here. I'm surprised that there aren't that many courses by him. Language and sound were perfectly clear, though the tone was slightly monotonous, but it did not affect the great explanations. 
I've been trying to pickup GraphQL for a while now but resources were limited and some were not good enough. This course has hit its target right on for me, and actually made GraphQL a lot easier to learn. Very highly recommended to anyone wanting to learn GraphQL, though a good knowledge of JavaScript, Node, some react, and API development in general will make this course much more useful and easier to follow.
Finally, it would be very useful to add to the course a section that explains the use of Query/Mutations components  from Apollo Client in react. It would make a very nice complement to this course.
Thanks a lot, Mr Nasato, for what I think is an excellent course, looking forward for more of your work.

results.content:
Arguably, the best course on Udemy.  I would love for the instructor to produce more courses on GraphQL and Apollo.  There is a gap in this area and it is apparent he understand the material.  

A few ideas include a deep-dive into ApolloBoost, Apollo-Provider, client-side error handling, pagination, optimistic-UI, etc.  On the server side provide material on Data Loader.

 Maybe explore the Apollo tools such as Apollo Engine and Dev Tools.

In sum, build an end-to-end real-world application.

results.content: A quite good and informative course which gives you a general understanding of GraphQL. As a recommendation, you can add some additional info to the section: Apollo Client with React Hooks. Thanks a lot for this course.

results.content: Wow.  This is an extremely high quality course.  The instructor packs a huge amount of information into 5.5 hours.  The content is exceptionally well planned and delivered.  Mirko takes a very methodical approach to teaching ... carefully building up fundamental concepts and then building on them.  He also takes care to quickly recap key points regularly which contributes greatly to the overall effectiveness of the course.  The course projects are also well presented and easy to follow along with to reinforce the learning.  The course was a pleasure to take.
